ResponsesInList.Title: Feedback activity - guest role
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear all, I would like to find out whether anyone has successfully implemented Feedback activity for guests. Using all the information I could find (forum topics 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 ), I followed these steps Using¬†2.4.3 (Build: 20130318) Enabled - installed and enabled Feedback Frontpage location - added the activity to Frontpage Mapping - feedback was mapped to a course Front page role - changed the default front page role (to guest) Permissions - ensured that guest on global, course and feedback level has¬†mod/feedback:complete &¬†mod/feedback:view Login - logged in as a guest Access the feedback PROBLEM - cannot see 'Answer the questions...', only a preview which doesn't save the response (invalid course ID) Is this because Moodle 2.0+ does not allow guests to write anything into the database ? Is there any way to override this at the system level? I have a couple of strong use cases for guests being able to fill out feedback/questionnaire/surveys. If the concern was cross-site scripting attacks - this could be prevented by disabling all roles to view reports and creating a role solely for viewing questionnaire/feedback/survey reports. It just seems hardcoding the guest access is rather harsh (what would be the point of even listing the write permissions in their role). Many thanks in advance, I am desperate

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback activity - guest role
ResponsesInList.Text: Martin " Is this because Moodle 2.0+ does not allow guests to write anything into the database? " Yes! On the related question of (not) allowing anonymous respondents/guests to submit a Questionnaire, see this discussion . Please note that, further to that discussion I have for the moment given up implementing respondents/guests respondents to the Questionnaire plugin. As I see it, the rationale is that Moodle is a CMS primarily aimed at enrolled users (students), hence the restrictions imposed on "(anonymous) visitors/guests". Especially writing rights (to the database). If you desperately need persons not enrolled in your Moodle site/courses to submit responses to a survey-like activity, then I suggest using the excellent LimeSurvey open source software. Joseph (maintainer of the Questionnaire plugin).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback activity - guest role

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback activity - guest role

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback activity - guest role
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, so I have this working perfectly. ¬†This is how I achieved it. ¬†I did not change the default front page role. ¬†Mine is set to authenticated user. ¬†I added the complete a feedback permission to both the guest role and the authenticated user role. ¬†I then allowed anonymous submissions (very important) in the feedback activity. ¬†I did not map to courses - I think this might be your issues. ¬†If you are letting anyone submit it, you cannot map to courses as they would have to be in a course. Anyone can go to my Front Page and submit the feedback. ¬†Obviously this lays the feedback open to unwanted spam attacks so I circumvent this by adding a password as the first question and making the next question conditional upon the correct answer being put in the password field.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback activity - guest role
ResponsesInList.Text: You have to add a page break after your Password question. ¬†Then make the second question (on the second page now) conditional on the answer to the first question. ¬†You might need to make the second question required to stop it jumping to the third.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback activity - guest role
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you everyone for your suggestions.¬† There are reasons why we specifically want to use Moodle for this survey, rather than one of the on-line alternatives.¬† The missing piece of the jigsaw was: a page break after the second (conditional and required) question, as well as one after the password question.¬† I've also inserted a label on the second question page explaining that if there is no question on the page it means that the password has been entered incorrectly and that the user should click 'Cancel' and try again.¬† Otherwise the operation becomes confusing for a legitimate user who has just made a mistake with the password. Thanks again!

ResponsesInList.Title: Remove "Mode" string
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Everyone, Good day. I just want to know if anyone here knows how to remove the Mode string: eg. "Mode: User's name will be logged and shown with answers" I tried editing the language pack but it did not change the string on the actual feedback itself. Anyone who has an idea, please let us know. Thank you! Regards, Miguel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Remove "Mode" string
ResponsesInList.Text: This line is probably more than one string. You can set all of them to empty or space in your languages pack, but you have to watch that there are not used in multiple locations, like settings for example. Note that string are being cached by Moodle, so changing the string may not have immediate effect. Also, the browser's caching may get into the way. An alternative would be to comment out the line in code that produces this line in the output.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How does the block Feedback work?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Monica, sorry for the missing "autonumbering.html" . I added it today to the cvs and in the next time it will be included in the zip-package. "Map feedback to courses" has nothing to do with "URL for continue-button". The "URL for continue-button" is the possibility to redirect users to a special location after submitting a feedback. With "Map feedback to courses" you can define which courses (that means members of this courses) can submit this feedback. This button is only visible on feedbacks on the frontpage. If you do not map courses at all so this feedback will be shown on all courses. The goal is to collect data from different course in one feedback. Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: My bad, was Re: How does the block Feedback work?
ResponsesInList.Text: mmm Glenys, why not just a simple "Sorry" or "I'm sorry"or "Well, I made a mess of that, sorry." <diatribe> "My bad" would reflect a cultural inclination to the simplistic and semi-literate standard as being acceptable use of language, much in the same vein as "never ever", perhaps. While I am certainly no Grammar Nazi, see this very funny YouTube video clip, YouTube video I do like my English to be almost accurate. I would much prefer the English of Dickens, or Joyce, or Shaw or even the Dreadful Dan Brown to "my bad". Equally, I understand that the dynamics of language often drive it in directions the purists would not want to go and after a short time colloquialisms can often become part of the language but not all of them are really beneficial, or edifying. I also accept that many, many more colloquialisms are used in a specific era, for a specific purpose, then dropped by the next generation as being inane, or no longer serving the purpose they did serve. Please look at the wonderful documentary video by Melvin Bragg on "The Adventure of English" and you will get a better sense of what I am talking about here. </diatribe> In this short, for me, gripe there are several grammatical errors, a run on sentence and a dangling participle. I am sorry I did not pick up on this discussion earlier, I wasn't really paying attention, you see.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How does the block Feedback work?
ResponsesInList.Text: How to create a feedback on the main site of my moodle-installation and how to make it invisible to teachers and make only the¬†feedback questions visible to students and analysis report visible to manager.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How does the block Feedback work?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, how to use global feedbacks with the feedback-block is described here: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=155450&parent=681194 Per default a feedback at the frontpage is unaccessable at all. All users in your moodle installation on the frontpage only are "authenticated users". You must give them the permission to complete the feedback by changing the permissions of that feedback. # Login as admin # Go into the feedback located on the frontpage # Click at the "Settings" block on "Permissions" # Right of the permission "Complete a feedback" you can find a plus-icon (+). Click on this. # Select the role "Authenticated user" and click on "Allow" Now users and also teachers can complete this global feedback with clicking at the link in the feedback-block. I'm hoping it helps a bit. Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback activity no longer visible
ResponsesInList.Text: I think I have found the issue http://docs.moodle.org/24/en/Capabilities/mod/feedback:view <paste> Capabilities/mod/feedback:view This allows a user to view a feedback activity This capability is allowed for the default roles of manager. teacher, non-editing teacher, student and guest In Moodle 2.4.6 onwards, feedback links on the course page and in the navigation are only displayed for users who have this capability. ResponsesInList.Title: A branched sequence using the Feedback activity and depend items
ResponsesInList.Text: Firstly, a bit of a disclaimer. ¬†I know what I'm proposing here is not what Feedback was originally intended for, but I don't think that makes it a bad idea. ¬†I'm interested in well, feedback ( ) from the community on whether this is a good idea, and worth pursuing. ¬†Here goes! Lesson allows us to create branching activities that individual students can do, but it never shows a student how the rest of the class answered a particular question, or how the class did on the activity as a whole. If we could show this back to students, it could be used to prompt discussion on how students progress through a case study analysis for example. Feedback should technically be capable of this for a non-gradable activity. ¬†By creating a sequence of questions using depend items within them, we *should* technically be able to create a branched activity. ¬†Except that it doesn't quite work (see tracker item https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-40689 ) Lesson suffers a bit from being a little clunky and time consuming to create, however Feedback is relatively quick and easy. So; could Feedback be a viable alternative to Lesson for practice tasks and conversation starters with follow on activities such as Forum and Chat? ¬†Would anyone else consider it for this purpose?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: A branched sequence using the Feedback activity and depend items
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lindy, I don't understand your question. You can create a chain of questions which depend on previously given answers. I have an example question set attached so you can test it. You can easy import it into your feedback. Best regards Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: A branched sequence using the Feedback activity and depend items
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi folks! Thanks for taking the time to respond, I really appreciate it! Andreas resolved my tech difficulty on the tracker item - I had added one too many page breaks (in my enthusiasm!), and broke the activity as a result.¬† Once that was fixed, the Feedback file worked beautifully. Beyond the tech question though, I guess I'm asking are there any other folks who would consider bending Feedback in this manner a good idea? In my consulting work, I find folks often get frustrated with the clunkiness of Lesson (even though I think its a great tool), but Feedback is a little quicker and easier to setup.¬† Unlike Lesson, Feedback has an option for us to display responses, anonymised or identified, back to the students.¬† I think sharing responses after the student has made their own personal choices could be a good tool for more reflective practice.¬† I also think one of the challenges facing online learners is feeling isolated and unsure of whether they're on the "right track" in the activities. I'm currently working on a mock up of a Feedback activity to share here, but it will probably take me another day or two to get it in good shape.¬† Hopefully, a file can demonstrate what I mean! Thank you again, will post more asap. Lindy

ResponsesInList.Title: Guest access and Feedback functionality very misleading for Teachers
ResponsesInList.Text: Using 2.4.3+ Guest access and Feedback functionality is very misleading for Teachers. The documentation is clear in that Guests can only use Feedback successfully on the front page of the Moodle yet, when Guests log in and access a Feedback within a course, by default, Moodle allows the Guest to click on the preview icon, fill out the form and click Continue.¬†¬† The Guest doesn't necessarily know this is only a preview and that the results will not be saved.¬† There is no error or warning message and it appears to let the Guest complete the Feedback which is misleading to the Guest and the Teacher administering the site. I have found a way to get around this by modifying the Guest role so they are not able to view Feedbacks but my question is why would a guest even be allowed to access/preview a Feedback in a course if the functionality is disabled here?¬† What purpose does this serve if they cannot save results?¬† If there is a use-case for this, It might be useful to implement a warning at the very least so that guests are aware they are only previewing the Feedback and not actually completing the feedback.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Guest access and Feedback functionality very misleading for Teachers
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Susan, thank you for this post. You are right the "Continue" button could be some confusing. I think I could change that to a "Back" button. Would that be better? Best regards Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Guest access and Feedback functionality very misleading for Teachers
ResponsesInList.Text: Changing the continue button to something like 'Close Preview' might help. Although, I still think some sort of warning might be warranted here.¬† I think a pop up when the Guest clicks on the preview icon would be ideal.¬† Something like "This is only a preview, any changes made in this form will not be saved" Or, having the Guest preview capability set in the Feedback settings with the default being off.¬† Then those that really need this capability can turn it on accordingly. Thank-you for your consideration!

ResponsesInList.Title: notifications delivered to group teachers when student NOT allocated to a group

Non-editing teachers permissions are set to receive quiz notifications and feedback activity notifications. Non-editing teachers permissions are set NOT allow access to all groups. Here's the problem. When a student is in a group the e-mail notifications are delivered to the respective non-editing teachers as expected for both submission of the quiz and the feedback activity. When a student is NOT in a group the e-mail notifications for the submission of the Quiz are not delivered to any non-editing teachers, as expected. BUT, when a student is NOT in a group the e-mail notifications for the submission of the Feedback activity ARE delivered to all non-editing teachers, which is not expected. Any thoughts would be most welcome.

ResponsesInList.Title: View feedback in one page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm using moodle feedback 2.4. and i also use a condition if answer yes go to question no 2. to do this i need to add page break. but i want my feedback question all display in one page. how can i do that?
role: Picture of Ahmad Fitri Abdul Ghani

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: View feedback in one page
ResponsesInList.Text: You can't do that. The Dependencies feature of the Feedback module needs page breaks to be inserted between each "dependent" item, as is clearly explained in the online Help: First, create an item on which another item will depend on. Next, add a pagebreak. Then add the items dependent on the value of the item created before. Choose the item from the list labelled "Dependence item" and write the required value in the textbox labelled "Dependence value". Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle 1.9 Feedback calculation of averages
ResponsesInList.Text: We‚Äôve been using the Feedback module for¬†some time. Up to now, the¬†Feedbacks¬†are set for single submission, using: ¬∑ ‚ÄòRequired‚Äô ¬†‚ÄòMultiple choice (rated) single answer allowed (dropdown list); and ¬∑ Optional ‚ÄòLonger text answers‚Äô. This setup works entirely reliably and the exported Excel workbook provides calculated averages for the numerically rated questions ‚Äì which is what we need. The calculation of averages is based on the ‚Äòrequirement‚Äô for each respondent to give a numerically rated value before the Feedback will be accepted when ‚ÄòSubmit‚Äô is selected. If a ‚Äòrequired‚Äô answer has been omitted, the individual‚Äôs responses are no accepted, and the user is prompted to supply a numerically-rated answer. For every numerically-rated answer, the average is calculated as the sum of each numerical value x the frequency of that value/the total number of people submitting responses to the Feedback. I‚Äôve just introduced a different style of¬†Feedback¬†set to allow ‚ÄòMultiple submit‚Äô. This means that students can complete one Feedback¬†progressively through an¬†8-week residential course. When they select ‚ÄòSubmit‚Äô, their answers are recorded and saved. They can then re-enter the Feedback to add new responses and, if they wish, amend earlier responses in the light of course developments. Again, the Feedback employs a mixture of ‚ÄòMultiple choice (rated) single answer allowed (dropdown list); and ‚ÄòLonger text answers‚Äô. ¬∑ However, it is not practical to set the Multiple choice (rated) questions to ‚ÄòRequired‚Äô. ¬∑ If that were done, then in, say, week one, all the students would have to give ratings for every week covered by the Feedback in order to ‚ÄòSubmit‚Äô, even though the course had not yet dealt with the topics to which the questions related. Unfortunately, the Feedback calculation of averages does not cope with unreliable human beings! For each numerically-rated question, the average is the sum of each numerical value x the frequency of that value/the total number of people submitting responses to the Feedback. The algorithm does not take account of the number of people answering the question . The two are not necessarily then same, and therefore the automatically-calculated averages are not correct. Our¬†need for this new style¬†of using the Feedback module will increase in importance. So‚Ä¶ Is it possible to modify the Feedback module to calculate averages based on the number of respondents to each question, rather than the maximum number of respondents to the Feedback as a whole?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback visible but not accessible
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Nancy, I don't know that I understood all right. I think you have to place a feedback inside the moodle frontpage. There you have to give the needed rights to complete this feedback. The most common setting is to give the "Authenticated user" or the "Authenticated user on frontpage" the permission to complete this feedback. This setting you have to set on the feedback itself. ResponsesInList.Title: How to obtain individual Trainer feedback results
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi. I am part of an organisation that has 2000 employees attending a mixture of face to face and elearning modules as part of their induction training. We induct between 400-600 new employees each year. I have set up feedback forms for¬†each face to face session¬†throughout the learners induction on moodle. Each face to face will most probably have a different trainer. What I want to be able to do is now measure the feedback forms via the¬†trainer who ran each course so we can measure knowledge and satisfaction. I understand that I could group learners into a group for each trainer, but that learner won't have the same trainer for each face to face. And I can't have lots of different feedback forms to suit each trainer either. Is there a way to pick from a drop down list, who the trainer was on the face to face so that I can then pull responses by trainer? Any guidance would be greatly appreciated!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to obtain individual Trainer feedback results
ResponsesInList.Text: I just add a drop down list of all teachers and have the student pick which one they had. I have found that to be the simplest way to accomplish what you are looking for.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to obtain individual Trainer feedback results

From a line manager point of view, if I wanted to them pull feedback analysis¬†via trainer, how would I do this? As when I look at the responses and analysis it just shows how many times a learner has picked their name. The¬†only way I know would be to add each learner to a group for each trainer, but the administration behind this is too much for us. As 1 learner may see 4 trainers. If you have any further advice, I'd really appreciate it. Simon

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to obtain individual Trainer feedback results
ResponsesInList.Text: I always export all the responses to Excel and then filter them there - that way I can filter for each teacher and then I just copy those results over to separate sheet that I can then share with the teacher. You can export right from the feedback activity. ¬†You will get two sheets in the spreadsheet - the second sheet has the detailed responses.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No email notifications when feedback is set to separate groups (M2.2)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Hartmut, I looked at your installation. The reason is simple. You have one group for students and one group for teachers. Your students are in their group and the teachers are in their group. But the teachers are not in the students group. If you have separated groups so the teachers can not receive a message from another group than a group where they are assigned to. That's the sense of separated groups. You have put both groups into the one single grouping but that isn't the same. A grouping does not merge groups. It is just a defninition of an amount of groups. You can use groupings to control the visibility of course activities. But separated groups are left separated. In a single sentence: To solve your problem you have to assign the teachers to the students group. That's all . Best regards Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No email notifications when feedback is set to separate groups (M2.2)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No email notifications when feedback is set to separate groups (M2.2)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Hartmut, in my point of view it works as it should. The capability "Access all groups" means "access" and not "receive messages". If it would also mean "receive messages" so any admin or manager would receive messages from all feedback submissions on the whole site. With groups you have a tool you can control of what part you want to get messages. For example: You have a course with four teachers. Each teacher coaches one group in parts of the course. In fact these teachers only want to receive messages from the own group and not from all. Best regards Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No email notifications when feedback is set to separate groups (M2.2)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andreas, Thank you for your reply and for the example. I also understand that ‚ÄúAccess all groups,‚Äù the default capability for teachers which is set to allow, means access to all groups in the context they are assigned to. In a course context any user with a teacher capability will have access to all groups in this particular course by default. The Groups FAQ deal with the question of having more than one teacher in a course like in your example. Under ‚ÄúHow do I restrict a teacher to view only information about the groups that they are in?‚Äù they confirm that all teacher roles in this course will have access to all groups unless the default capability of ‚ÄúAccess all groups‚Äù is changed. (this is not in the documentation) If I want to restrict access of a teacher to his own group with separate group mode enabled, I need to change ‚ÄúAccess all groups‚Äù from ‚ÄúAllow‚Äù to either ‚ÄúNot set‚Äù or ‚ÄúPrevent‚Äù in permissions on a course level , not a system level. On an activity level I need to locally assign the role of a non-editing teacher to the teacher in a particular group activity because ‚Äúthe non-editing teacher can only see the groups of which they are a member‚Äù (Groups FAQ). If email notification and separate groups are enabled in the Feedback activity of a course with a locally assigned non-editing teacher to the activity of his group, why does this non-editing teacher not receive emails? The non-editing teacher is not in any group, only assigned to the activity of his group. If I change the same Feedback activity to visible groups, the non-editing teacher receives emails. With kind regards, Hartmut

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No email notifications when feedback is set to separate groups (M2.2)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Hartmut, please don't mix groups and roles. That are very different things. You can assign a user local to the activity, at course level or just give the capability global. That all has the same result: the user has the capability to receive email from feedback. But the capability is not the only condition that is checked. If you have separated groups the user has to be a member of this group the feedback is submitted from. Best regards Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No email notifications when feedback is set to separate groups (M2.2)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andreas, Thanks for all the responses and your patience. The least that I can say after many comments in this forum thread is that separate groups with email notifications enabled don‚Äôt seem to be consistent within the Moodle activities. The teacher in the same course will receive emails from separate groups in a Forum activity (where he or she is not a member of any group), but not in Feedback activity. This is what I observed and tested in the last days in Moodle 2.2 and 2.4. The good news is that I found a solution. As the teacher is able to receive emails in the Feedback activity when the group mode is set to visible, but the student will only see his or her answers, but not the answers of other groups, I will go with this approach. Thanks again, Andreas, for providing this module and for the forum moderation. With kind regards, Hartmut

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback and certificates
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok - just figured this out! ¬†Something I have been wanting to set up so thanks for the question - it prompted me to figure it out!! 1. Completion tracking and conditional access must be turned on Admin/Advanced Features 2. They must also be turned on in Course Settings. 3. Then, for the Feedback, under completion settings set completed as being submitted. 4. Once that is done, in your certificate, set conditional settings as only being visible/available once Feedback activity is completed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback Template "public" tick box
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sami, sitewide templates are related to a global context . So you can not give some rights at course level. You have to give the right global. One way could be to create a new empty role "templatecreator". For this role allow the creation of public templates. Then put all teachers you want to have the right into this role global. Best regards Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback Template "public" tick box
ResponsesInList.Text: Just in case anyone gets to this thread from Google, I have documented how to do this here: Template creator

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback Template "public" tick box
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Dave, the feature to use sitewide templates is available in Moodle 2.2.x upwards. In 2.0 to 2.1 it was disabled. Best regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create a 'Feedback" for teachers to answer
ResponsesInList.Text: Just make a new course -add your teachers to it as students and make the feedback there. They will be able to complete it no problem.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create a 'Feedback" for teachers to answer
ResponsesInList.Text: I could do that, but I was hoping for a way to do this collaboration inside the same course. This suggestion would mean that I'd have potentionally to reflect all the course structure with a parallel, teacher-only structure. Thanks for the suggestion anyway, Fadi

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create a 'Feedback" for teachers to answer
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Fadi, if you already have the teacher in a single course it should be possible to use a feedback inside this course. Can you just tell what version of moodle do you use? Is this a version upgraded from 1.9? In 1.9 the completion for teachers was forbidden by default. In 2.x this permission is not set. If you have an upgraded version you should go to "Site administration/Users/Permissions/Define roles". Go to the role editingteacher and than edit this. Switch to the advanced view. Search the permission "mod/feedback:complete" and select "Not set". Now you should be able to override this role inside your feedback-instance in your course. I hope it helps Best regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create a 'Feedback" for teachers to answer
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your response, I should have pointed that I'm using version 2.2.5+. I tried to do as you described, but there seem to be a problem with this. I tried to set it to enabled, and this made teachers able to answer feedbacks site-wide. What I would like is that I have to option to give them this role on select feedbacks. Could this be a "feature" of 2.2?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create a 'Feedback" for teachers to answer
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Fadi, as I mentioned before you have to override the permission in the feedback-instance its self. 1) Go into your course 2) Click on your feedback you want to use for your teachers 3) Click on "Permissions" inside the block "Settings" 4) In the dropdown list "Advanced role override" choose "Teacher" or how ever your teacher role is named 5) Look for "mod/feedback:complete" and set it to "Allow" 6) Click on "Save changes" Your teachers should be able to complete this feedback now. Best regards Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create a 'Feedback" for teachers to answer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create a 'Feedback" for teachers to answer
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Fadi, you have to do this as a user with the permission to override the teacher role. If you don't have this permission you should ask your administrator to give you that or do the setting for you. Best regards Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create a 'Feedback" for teachers to answer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create a 'Feedback" for teachers to answer
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Fadi, the grouping functionality is used to control the access to a module. What do you want is the group feature. To use this you have to activate the "Group mode" setting inside your feedback instance. 1) Go into your feedback 2) Go to "Edit settings" 3) Select "Separate groups" or "Visible groups" on the "Group mode" setting. After that you can see a new dropdown list in which you can choose the group you want to filter. Best regards Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create a 'Feedback" for teachers to answer
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, as a teacher you can't excluding yourself. That's why you can see "All participants" too. Best regards Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Captcha not working as Feedback question
ResponsesInList.Text: The captcha field uses google recaptcha, so you need to open a google recaptcha account, get the public and private keys and enter them in Settings > Site administration > Plugins > Authentication > Manage authentication .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Captcha not working as Feedback question

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback module-responses for individual students not showing
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for this Andreas Below are the current sttings. Which of the following do we turn on? Will this then show the responses to my feedback? Cheers Lucien Debugging Debug messages debug NONE: Do not show any errors or warningsMINIMAL: Show only fatal errorsNORMAL: Show errors, warnings and noticesALL: Show all reasonable PHP debug messagesDEVELOPER: extra Moodle debug messages for developers Default: NONE: Do not show any errors or warnings If you turn this on, then PHP's error_reporting will be increased so that more warnings are printed. This is only useful for developers. Display debug messages debugdisplay Default: No Set to on, the error reporting will go to the HTML page. This is practical, but breaks XHTML , JS, cookies and HTTP headers in general. Set to off, it will send the output to your server logs, allowing better debugging. The PHP setting error_log controls which log this goes to. XML strict headers xmlstrictheaders Default: No Set to on, each page will be generated using XML http headers and prolog, so browsers will show XHTML errors inline. This is only useful for developers. Debug email sending debugsmtp Default: No Enable verbose debug information during sending of email messages to SMTP server. Performance info perfdebug Default: No If you turn this on, performance info will be printed in the footer of the standard theme Show origin of languages strings debugstringids Default: No This option is designed to help translators. It shows the language file and string id beside each string that is output. (Changing this setting will only take effect on the next page load.) Show validator links debugvalidators Default: No Enable if you want to have links to external validator servers in page footer. You may need to create new user with username w3cvalidator , and enable guest access. These changes may allow unauthorized access to server, do not enable on production sites! Show page information debugpageinfo Default: No Enable if you want page information printed in page footer.

Label gets 255 characters. Then, instead of just the numbers to pick from, add all the possibilites as part of the multiple choice values. The multiple choice values is a text field which if I'm not mistaken gets to be up to¬† ~32k characters. To save on repetitive typing for additional questions, you would need to type the 1 thru 10 stuff just once, change the question, then click on Save as New Question.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: character limits

ResponsesInList.Title: Administering central feedback
ResponsesInList.Text: We have a centralized student feedback process in our school. I am investigating whether we could shift it into Moodle once we fully¬†synchronise all our students and courses in Moodle (so that we don't need to handle two different systems). I like the feedback module and the feedback block and I have managed to set up a trial on our server . We have Moodle 2.2.2 on out test server but plan to upgrade to 2.3 soon (both the test and the production one). My questions: My dream-solution would be to have a feedback block on the front page that contains all the links of the course-feedback that each student should fill in (as many as the number of courses the student has been registered to). At the moment it seems to me that the course links are only available through the feedback block under the course. My vision is a feedback block that is similar to the "Course overview" block that would list all the feedback activities that are still open and have not been answered yet. Has anyone programmed this or something similar already? If No1 is difficult to set up, then a "can-live-with-it" option could be to have the feedback links under each course. But how can I "force" the feedback block to be visible in all courses automatically while the feedback session is open? (I could only manage to add the feedback block to a course manually one by one so far...) And how do I make sure that the teachers do not modify this specific block (e.g. hiding it) while I would like to allow them to modify other blocks in general? My last question is in connection with viewing the responses. If I set the feedback so that it is not anonymous, then the "Show responses" will generate the errors below. Error: mdb->get_record() found more than one record!line 1309 of \lib\dml\moodle_database.php: call to debugging()line 1269 of \lib\dml\moodle_database.php: call to moodle_database->get_record_ sql ()line 1249 of \lib\dml\moodle_database.php: call to moodle_database->get_record_select()line 242 of \mod\feedback\show_entries.php: call to moodle_database->get_record() I know that it is because there are more responses of a single student and I have set up the feedback so that each of them would accept 1 answer only for each course. So it is hard to find which student has not answered which course's feedback. However, the analysis and the export works properly, containing all the answers of the various courses Thank you for any help. √âva

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Administering central feedback
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Eva, thank your for your good ideas. The second one (2) is easy to achieve. You have to create a instance of the feedback-block at the frontpage. Go into the settings page of this block. Select on the "page contexts" the value "Display throughout the entire site". The block will now be shown at all courses The third thing I will look asap. Best regards Andreas

It seems that the block can only show 1 link at a time (is this how it was desgned to work?). When I mapped the feedback activities to a disjoint set of courses, the link in the course feedback blocks were correct. Steps in detail: Create 2 feedback activities on the front page and leave them both available on all courses (no mapping) >> result: all courses will show only 1 link in the block - the one that links to the 2nd activity Map the 2 activities to courses so that each course is mapped to one of the feedback activities >> result: feedback block will show the correct activity link for each course. When I start mapping the courses, this error message appears: You should set baseurl when using flexible_table. line 481 of \lib\tablelib.php: call to debugging() line 131 of \mod\feedback\mapcourse.php: call to flexible_table->setup() . Is there anything configured wrong in my site? Best regards, √âva

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there anyway I can hide the activity link?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there. Instead of creating your feedback in the central area, add the main menu block and create your feedback there. Get its URL and paste into your custom menu as you did before and hide the main menu block with the eye. Even though the block is hidden the feedback activity will not be hidden and so they will be able to view and do it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there anyway I can hide the activity link?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there anyway I can hide the activity link?
ResponsesInList.Text: So that's what the main menu block is for. I hacked the core code to the effect that I can hide items by setting. Top: items in edit mode; the first six show also the description inside the item link. Bottom: items when editing off; only the first six which are set to show description are visible.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there anyway I can hide the activity link?
ResponsesInList.Text: Very nice.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there anyway I can hide the activity link?
ResponsesInList.Text: You can hide the activity link by css . The link resides in li tag. Use the browser inspector to find the id of the li tag which should be something like: Ii#module-70.activity.feedback.modtype_feedback With this id you can add a css definition in the theme or on the front page (in a label) such as: Ii#module-70.activity.feedback.modtype_feedback { display:none; } The other issue is one of the main reasons I stopped using the Feedback for this purpose. I use instead a designated Dataform view which always open a new message form (also after a successful submission).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there anyway I can hide the activity link?

Updated versions are available at http://substantialmethods.com/course/view.php?id=4 , are tested against and should be compatible with the latest stable Moodle version. The designated contact view is not yet posted for download but should be soon.

ResponsesInList.Title: Converting feedback answers into useful information for all users...
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I'm using the feedback module in order to let users report actions they have done offline. By doing it we pretend to achieve two purposes: - in the admin side, obtain a global statistic of what is being done. By exporting to Excel the submitted data we can do it. - in the user side, we would like to allow all the users to see the answers submitted by others, in order to inspire them for future actions. We have granted all users the "non-editing teacher" role so they can access the answers list and browse every single answer. The results are not bad but we would like to improve the user experience. Does anybody know of a plugin that could convert the feedback answers into a public list of resources (pages) for instance? Any ideas on how doing this? Any help would be appreciated. Thanks in advance! Jaume

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Converting feedback answers into useful information for all users...
ResponsesInList.Text: For those interested on this subject, we finally decided to replace the feedback activity by a database one. We lose some features (required fields, simple analysis upon submitted answers and a few more) but we earn editing capabilities and flexibility on layouts (templates), as well as for inputs as for outputs. And also there is no need to deal with roles and permissions, because by default everybody has the right to see others entries. Jaume

ResponsesInList.Title: Feedback : email notification doesn't link to response
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, The feedback activity email notification I am receiving does not link to the specific response that triggered the email... How do I know which answer was submitted? I'm sure I'm doing something wrong. Can anyone help me with this? Thank you in advance, susana

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback : email notification doesn't link to response
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Susana, unfortunately the feedback notification mail only is linked to the feedback-instance but not to the single response. If your feedback is not anonymous so you can look at the sender address. That's the user who submited the feedback. Best regards Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback : email notification doesn't link to response
ResponsesInList.Text: Use "export to excel", In that exported excel file you can find two sheets "testfeedback" and "detailed". In "detailed" sheet you can find full details of feedback. Try it once Regards, Brahmaiah Petluri ( Edited by Helen Foster to remove signature according to our moodle.org forums code of conduct - original submission Monday, 23 April 2012, 08:16 AM )

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback : email notification doesn't link to response
ResponsesInList.Text: Andreas and Brahamaiah, thank you for your comments!! Brahamaiah, I was not able to find any extra information on excel file... I am using anonymous... A feedback timestamp would be¬†enough Thanks, susana

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback : email notification doesn't link to response
ResponsesInList.Text: HI, You have to modify the moodle core code. Go to "mod\feedback\lib.php"....search for function "feedback_send_email_anonym"....and edit line below: $info->url = $CFG-> wwwroot .'/mod/feedback/show_entries_anonym.php?id='.$cm->id; your required url is : /feedback/show_entries_anonym.php?id=60& do_show =& showall =& showcompleted =5 So get the remaining parameters and add them to "$info->url"....then you will get the required url to ur mail. Regards, Brami.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback : email notification doesn't link to response
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Ok, thanks. I believe that the '5' from "showcompleted=5" in your example, is the entry id. But which variable gives you that parameter? ("id=60" is id=$cm->id... "showcompleted=5" is showcompleted=????) Thanks, susana

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: permission feedback to simple user
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mariam, I don't know what an enseignement feedback is. To complete a feedback the both capabilities "feedback:view" and "feedback:complete" must be permitted. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: permission feedback to simple user
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mariam, Moodle 2.x click on your feedback go at the left site to Settings -> Feedback administration -> Permissions At the line started with "Complete a feedback" click on the plus icon and add the role "Authenticated user" and then click on the button "Allow". Moodle 1.9.x click on the update icon click on the tab "Override permissions" click on "Authenticated user" At the line started with "Complete a feedback" activate the option "Allow" and click on "Save changes" Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: How does feedback behave when migrating to 2.x?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello; I'm installing Feedback now on 1.9.6, and I have some concerns about what will happen when we eventually migrate to 2.x. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How does feedback behave when migrating to 2.x?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi David, the feedback module included in moodle 2.x is a directly upgrade from the contrib feedback module in 1.9. That means that you will not loose any data or settings after your upgrade. Best regards Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How does feedback behave when migrating to 2.x?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Need help using "depend item" and "depend value"
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andreas, Thanks for providing a "conditional branching/skip logic" feature in your Feedback module. However, the example you attached (conditionalquestions.xml) does not have a "logical flow". Scenario #1 Q1 Do you work at home? Student: Never Q2 Why do you work never at home? Student: "blah blah blah" Q3 What Os do you use at home? This is not logical . I would expect that if the student answered "Never" to question¬†1, the Survey would skip question 3. Scenario #2 So I modified question 3 to make it dependent on Q1 "every day": What Os do you use at home? (workathome->every day). Here is the new scenario. Q1 Do you work at home? Student: Every day Q2 What Os do you use at home? etc. it works OK until the end Scenario #2b Q1 Do you work at home? Student: Never it takes the student to the end of the Survey. The problem is that the choices "often, some day, seldom" should also go to the question about "which OK so you use", but they don't. The way to do this is to add new questions, like this: What Os do you use at home? (workathome->often). What Os do you use at home? (workathome->some days). What Os do you use at home? (workathome->seldom). It would be nice if we had a feature to add in the "depend item" "depend value" field not just one value, but a list of comma-separated values. So, in the example at hand, we would not have to multiply the number of questions, but have all "depend values" together in one question. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback : export answers to xls unusable
ResponsesInList.Text: I solved it. The problem to feedback19 is located in page analysis_to_excel.php(\mod\feedback) in line 69 $workbook->setVersion(8); Number 8 refers to a very old MS Office Version. You can check your Office version from the folder C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office12, Office12 comes from Office2007. So if we give a number between 9 -12 in the line above, the export to excell procedure, works fine. Sakis Zafeiropoulos

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback : export answers to xls unusable
ResponsesInList.Text: I have solved the problem changing the path in /mod/feedback/analysis_to_excel.php . At line 67 when appears /srv/www/moodledata , you change it with your actual moodledata path. Good luck!

ResponsesInList.Title: How to direct from Feedback to a file resource in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I want to add a questionnaire, to moodle using feedback module because, it is only in feedback, that moodle allows branching of questions. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to direct from Feedback to a file resource in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Shikhar, you can define a depend question for each item. That means you can put at the end of your feedback a label that depends on the answer of a question at beginning. In this label you can link a file or image or what you want. q1: chose yes or no pagebreak q2: question depending on yes q3: question depending on no q4: some other question q5: some other question pagebreak q6: label depending on yes q7: label depending on no Best regards Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Deleting Feedback template of other user
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I've been asked to update our Feedback templates (Moodle 1.9)¬†for consistency and delete¬†old¬†versions created by teaching staff in several departments. Trouble is although I can see the templates in the 'Use a template' menu, the only ones visible from 'Delete' are those created within that course. I'm not even sure some of the original courses are still available (but I'm assuming they must be on the system if the template is still there). As early-adopter staff have moved on since the templates were created I also can't just ask those individuals. Pity templates can't be accessed from the manage activities admin - that would much easier! So question is, do I need to trawl through several hundred courses to find these ' needles' - or can anyone suggest a better way of tracking down and deleting them - and if so what would the steps be? Thanks, Gordon.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deleting Feedback template of other user
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Gordon, you are right. In 1.9 the public templates can not be managed very usefull. In 2.2 there is a better aproach. If you have access to the database so you could change the values for the courseid in the table "feedback_template". Use a courseid of a course you want. After that you can manage all public feedback-templates in that course. Example- SQL if the courseid would be 10: UPDATE mdl_feedback_template set course = 10 WHERE ispublic = 1; If you have no access to the database so you have to find all templates manually . Best regards Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deleting Feedback template of other user
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andreas, Thanks - and good to know this is improved in 2.2! Am I understanding¬†correctly that the sql command you've illustrated will then set course "x" as having access to all public templates? That would be much easier than trawling to find them!Cheers, Gordon.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deleting Feedback template of other user
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Gordon, yes! In this way all public templates will be moved in that course. Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: [1.9.9] Feedback for students and Feedback for teachers
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, How can I do something like this? Two different feedback activities viewable each by students and by teachers? I would also like to post a block on the main page or even a sticky block, but having the same conditions. Thanks in advance

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: [1.9.9] Feedback for students and Feedback for teachers
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, in general the roles "student" and "teacher" only are affected in a course. So the feedbacks you need have to be located in the course where the students and teachers are assigned. If you want one feedback for students and one for the teachers so you could separate them with groupings. you can create two groups in your course and then two groupings. Then you create two feedbacks and restrict the access by groupings. The effect is that students and teachers only see the right feedback. Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multiple submit can't change
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Carlos, As soon as someone has submitted answers in the feedback activity, the "multiple submit" option cannot be changed. You can either delete all entries in the current activity or start a new activity without multiple submit. With kind regards, Hartmut

ResponsesInList.Title: Feedback - hide null answers in text fields/areas
ResponsesInList.Text:
This is a minor change that one of my curriculum developers requested. We are using moodle 1.9 When viewing the analysis of feedback containing text based answers she wanted to not show the responces where the user did not provide an answer. I accomplished this by adding an if statement to the textfield lib.php and the text area lib.php files.¬† The respective files can be found in the feedback folder under ../mod/feedback/item/textarea/lib.php and ../mod/feedback/item/textfield/lib.php Under the function print_analysed section look for the foreach statement foreach($values as $value) { echo '-  ' . str_replace("\n", '
', $value->value) . ''; } I added an if statement directly above the echo to echo only if the value was not null. Code is below.... foreach($values as $value) { if($value->value != ""){ echo '-  ' . str_replace("\n", '
', $value->value) . ''; } } I did the same to both the text field and text area questions... works like a charm. Jason

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Global Templates in Moodle 2.0?
ResponsesInList.Text: I ran into the same problem today and as far as I can see the problem still exists in moodle 2.1. My solution is to access the database after saving the template. So the steps would be: 1.) Save an existing feedback as template 2.) Access the moodle database, there should be a table mdl_feedback_template 3.) There's a column "ispublic". This is probably "false" for your new template 4.) Update this value to "true". After that I was able to see the template in all courses with different users.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback XML import/export utf8/ansi
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Miro, you UTF-8 file has a special signature at the beginning called BOM (Byte Order Mark). Some editors can show this but not all (see the screenshot). Most web-applications I know has problems with this. I don't know what tool do you use to create the xml-files. In any case you have to ensure that the file is saved in utf-8 without BOM. I am hoping it helps a bit. Andreas

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi.¬† I'm¬† using the feedback module to have our students evaluate their courses.¬† I have roughly 70 feedbacks open.¬† Is there an easier way to do this, to get a list of who has not completed which feedbacks?¬† As far as I can tell and based on your answer above, looking at log reports for all days will tell me who's completed each one, but then I'd have to either manually figure out who's not on that list or export the list of who's completed each one, put it into Access against a list of all students, and then run a query to show who's not completed the feedback. Is there a better way?? Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how can get remaining list of users who not give the feedback !
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Catherine, in the feedback-module for moodle 2.0 you can see users who has not responsed and send them a message but only if the feedback is not anonymous. In moodle 1.9 this feature is not implemented. Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how can get remaining list of users who not give the feedback !
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi.¬† It has to be anonymous... So that means there is no alternative to the way I'm doing it? Thanks again.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how can get remaining list of users who not give the feedback !
ResponsesInList.Text: Catherine - That is correct, if it is anonymous then you do not know who submitted and who did not. One of the critiques when anonymous was first introduced was that by logging it might be possible to determine who submitted which entries. I tried to randomize that but then folks said that you could just put a single user in a group and then sort by groups and see a particular users response and thus defeat anonymity. So then there is no logging of anonymous which means you do not know whether a particular user has completed an entry or not. As a teacher, I can understand wanting to ensure that every student has completed a feedback activity; however, if you compare it to the paper version of a survey there is no way to ensure that every student has in fact completed it. They can always turn one in blank and you would not know who that was. I would have to go back in and check to see if on an anonymous survey the viewing of the feedback is logged (as opposed to actually submitting one). Peace - Anthony

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how can get remaining list of users who not give the feedback !
ResponsesInList.Text: If you have a database developer or moodle programmer it is possible. Although it is anonymous, you can still get the user id from the moodle database. There is a table called mdl_feedback which is a list of all your feedbacks There is another table called mdl_user - all the users on your moodle installation Another table called mdl_feedback_completed - which relates mdl_feedback to mdl_user Using this third table, you can get a list of people who have not completed the feedback and compare it to a list of people on your course. (there are other tables like mdl_course you can use if you want to include filters for people on specific courses) Then either manually email them or again write a quick script to get moodle to email them all. This is usually a job for the E-Learning Developer if you have one. www.osiname.co.uk

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: multiple answer by same user simultaneously
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Daniel, the problem is that the feedback, if it is nonanonymous, saves only one post per user. If more than one users work with one account, in my opinion, only anonymous feedback makes sense. If you use some groups of users who should be separated you can use groups in the course and set the feedback to use groups. Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: multiple answer by same user simultaneously
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Daniel, ok, now I think I understand you . Can it be that you use pagebreaks in that feedback? If it is so after each break the state of the feedback is saved temporary. If just two users use the same account the second one will see the last saved temporary state. You could remove the pagebreaks and no state will be saved. I don't know how many questions do you use but it seams the only way to resolve your problem. Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Suggestions / wanted features for feedback
ResponsesInList.Text: Feedback is great module. I like and use it much. I have some suggestions / wanted features. I checked the forum and I have not found such a topic. I know Andreas is busy enough anyhow here they are: 1. Please add question type "grid" or "scale". I mean something like docs.google.com has for forms. In one question there are more rows and columns. In rows are options and in columns are weights. Weights may be open or 1,2,3.. or the Likert scale options: Strongly disagree, Disagree, Neither agree nor disagree, Agree, Strongly agree ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Likert_scale ) or Moodle Survey options: Almost never, Seldom, Sometimes, Often, Almost always. Answers are/should be stored in separate fields with names of rows (at least this is how it works in G. docs) 2. In setting-up the feedback (Edit Setting) add option (maybe in the Feedback options section) to Hide the "Not selected" No/Yes as a default option for the whole feedback (which will be default setting for the new feedback or will overwrite already set question (with warning)). In other words: additionally to the option provided for each question set the same for the whole feedback already at setting it up. 3. If the question is edited (not a newly created.. I guess you may check if the question is not the last one or question editor was reached by click on edit button) then please add in Edit Question on the bottom the new button "Save and edit next question" (next to buttons "Save changes to question" "Save as a new question" "Cancel") (and move to edit next question). 4. Pre-fill the labels field with something like SingleA1, MC2, TextS3, TextL4, Drop5 or similar for single answer, multiple choice, short, long text, drop down list etc. I mean something like: type of question+ number. The reason is that in Excel it would be meaningful to know the type of question (at least for me) without checking answers. It does not matter that user may change labels. I am guessing that most users let them empty anyway. 5. Small thing: in my installation (Moodle 2) in Templates/Use a template¬†the text: "No templates available yet" is rendered in two lines. Just one would be enough. This is just a case when there are no templates. I just looked into the source and found that it is because of size of div.fstaticlabel. Maybe I was not clear enough. Do not hesitate to add comments, suggestions.. Thanks Miro

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can't stop teachers from completing feedback

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can't stop teachers from completing feedback

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can't stop teachers from completing feedback
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Adedayo, in the case you described the feedback is in the context of your frontpage. A teacher generally is in her/his course enroled as teacher but not on the frontpage. There the teacher is like all other user only an authenticated user and not more. I would say there is no best way . If your installation has not to many teachers so you could create a new role with the wantet permissions and put the teacher in this role in the context of the frontpage or just the feedback self. ResponsesInList.Title: Multiple Submit Help Text
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm a bit confused by the following text, which is included as the contextual help on the Multiple Submit option in the feedback module.¬† If anyone can clarify or come up with a better, more easily understandable description, I would be more grateful.¬† This may have already been done since we installed the module, and if so, I apologize for not being more up to speed. Current text in our Feedback help file: "For Anonymous polls Multiple Submit will allow unlimited answers for every user. Where a User's name is collected, Multiple Submit will allow them allow to resubmit their Feedback answers."

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multiple Submit Help Text
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Buddy, there are two situations on what multiple submits are allowed. a) on anonymous feedback b) on nonanonymous feedback If a) so any submission by a user will create a new separate set of answers. If the user submits the feedback three times so the teacher will see three independent submissions on the analysis-page. If b) so the user only will create one set of answers. Each time the user want to do a new submission the user will see the answers from the submission before. The last submission is that what the teacher will see on the analysis-page. I'm hoping now it is a bit more clear . Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multiple Submit Help Text
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you Andreas.¬† That helps tremendously.

ResponsesInList.Title: Feedback module meet FERPA regulations?
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear all, just curious, does anyone know if the "feedback" module meets the FERPA (Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act) regulations, and have passed some accessibility tests?? Thanks! Wen

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback module meet FERPA regulations?
ResponsesInList.Text: That is an interesting question, but the Feedback module is, essentially, a survey tool so I am not sure that FERPA regs would even cover it. The Feedback module allows you to create your own surveys, and that would be well and truly policed by any schools, anyone else, well that would be an organizational thing so I doubt FERPA would even apply. As a general rule, one of the core policies of Moodle.org has been to preserve privacy wherever appropriate. The definition of "appropriate" applied by Moodle.org, in my view, has more than a touch of hysterical paranoia about it that is unnecessary. In so many areas Students should not even have an expectation of privacy from Teachers or the School, in general. Obviously this is limited by common sense and good taste, elements of our society that have been sadly lacking in recent decades. Unfortunately, the times we live in dictate that teachers are obviously suspect for wanting to work with children and therefore need to be limited by law to the point where they can no longer perform the duties expected of them. Obviously then, when it goes wrong, as it is, Teachers are being blamed for all of society's problems.

ResponsesInList.Title: Security for feedback activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there a way to limit access to a feedback activity the same ways that you can with the quiz module (mainly password and IP address)? The quiz module doesn't handle branching, so it's not appropriate for this particular task (a lab practicum with several versions, so different answers for some questions from version to version). It's not even a good data collection tool because you have to assign a right answer for every question. The feedback module makes the perfect simple data collection tool because we can collect the answers using a plain, basic form then export the responses to Excel and use SAS to process the data and assign grades. Unfortunately, this involves several hundred students taking the practicum during several class periods over several days and we want to be sure that they are accessing the activity only during their class period and only from our labs. It's probably not a huge issue because they will be given their test paper in class and must return it before they leave, but sometimes they can be crafty and the lead instructor is very cautious about security. I'd thought that the password protection and IP address limits were a Moodle feature rather than a module feature but discovered otherwise when I started digging around today. I know the feedback activity wasn't really design for this sort of thing but it's really perfect for it except for the lack of security features. Any suggestions? (Other than downloading the activity logs and red-flagging activities outside a student's lab time and/or not from our labs, which I'll do if that's what it takes and the lead instructor is satisfied with it...)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Security for feedback activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Liz, currently there is no such feature to restrict the access to the feedback-module . Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Security for feedback activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: Andreas, Thanks for the reply. The person for whom I'm doing this is satisfied with using groups/groupings to control access to the activity, so all is fine. I really appreciate being able to get the individual responses exported to the Excel workbook. That's making it possible for me to rework a lab practicum for computer grading in a class of 800-900 students. The practicums have been hand-graded in the past, so this is going to be a welcome change. liz

ResponsesInList.Title: Feedback Analysis:  Percentage for each answer for each question; mean and mode
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi. I'm using feedback for student evaluations of courses and instructors. It works fine, but we want to know what percentage of responders chose each answer for each question. Moodle can give us the raw numbers (i.e. 45 people chose answer A on question 3), but we're looking for percentage and also mean, mode, and standard deviation. Right now, we're exporting to Excel and using a macro to calculate this, but has anyone written an add on for this to be done within Moodle's analysis of feedback responses? Thanks in advance for the help.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback Analysis:  Percentage for each answer for each question; mean and mode
ResponsesInList.Text: Catherine: Right now, we're exporting to Excel and using a macro to calculate this,... This is the right thing to do. By using your own spreadsheet (or stats package) you are sure to process the data output by feedback exactly the way you want. Not only can you do all the calculations you need but you can output the results to any pie-chart you need. Making the equivalent processing available in the Feedback module itself would take a lot of programing time and ... then end-user would probably never be satisfied. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback does not send administrator an email
ResponsesInList.Text: Late answer (sorry) but I'm trawling through the Feedback Forum as I'm working with the Feedback module at the moment... I'm seeing this same behaviour in Moodle 1.9.9. The Feedback module documentation clearly indicates that Feedback results can be sent to the (site) Administrator. There is a simple drop down option in the activity settings. This function does not relate to Course Teachers.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback does not send administrator an email
ResponsesInList.Text: Site Admins usually turn off any emails directed to them everywhere they can, in self defence more than anything else. One person sending emails is OK, but if you have 35 in a course, then it becomes tedious and if you have more, it becomes overload.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback does not send administrator an email
ResponsesInList.Text: OK, well after some testing... Scenario: We added a Feedback to the front page of a site, and emails were not being sent. Solution: We added an individual as a Teacher ( not an Administrator) using the 'Locally assigned roles' of the Feedback activity. Emails sent - no problem This is a specific solution when using the Feedback module on the front page of a Moodle site. Adding the Feedback activity to a Course may well send the email to the Course Teacher(s) anyway? Hope this help, Stuart.

ResponsesInList.Title: Changing wording on "Submit your Answers" button
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Is there any way that you can change the wording on the "Submit you Answers" button as we want to change it to "Submit your Verification". Is this possible and if so how would I go about it. Kaz

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing wording on "Submit your Answers" button
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kaz, You can edit the "Submit you Answers" string as you would edit any language string in Moodle. Go to Administration ‚ñ∫ Language ‚ñ∫ Language editing / Local string customization. Edit words or phrases tab. Dropdown list (at the bottom, locate the feedback.php file line). Then in the feedback.php file locate the Submit your answer string, change to the new value and click on the Save changes button. Joseph PS.- May I say that I find the "Submit your Verification" wording rather strange? I expect it means something in your context.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing wording on "Submit your Answers" button

"Submit your Verification" is unusual because we used the feedback form more like an email form in this instance. It is used in a self paced staff training course where, when the participant has completed, they send off this feedback email so the¬†college is¬† alerted to their completion. They wanted 'submit your verification' wording to stop any confusion and make the process more direct. thanks again kaz

ResponsesInList.Text: I installed Feedback and right after the installation I received the following error: Module blocks: /home/eprofess/public_html/school/mod/blocks/version.php was not readable Then after I refreshed and I am know receiving the following two errors: Module "blocks" is not readable - check permissions Module "mod" is not readable - check permissions Strangely enough, the feedback activity works fine, but the errors at the top of the main page are annoying. Any ideas on how to stop them?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Module blocks: /home/eprofess/public_html/school/mod/blocks/version.php was not readable
ResponsesInList.Text: There is no module called "blocks" or "mod" so you have probably unzipped content of feedback zip package directly to yoursite/mod subfolder and not the site main folder. Delete folders /home/eprofess/public_html/school/mod/blocks and /home/eprofess/public_html/school/mod/mod and reinstall (unzip)¬†files of feedback so that you have folders /home/eprofess/public_html/school/mod/feedback and /home/eprofess/public_html/school/blocks/feedback Login back to your site and click Notifications (first link in administration menu) or visit http://www.yoursite.xxx/admin/index.php and you should not get those messages anymore.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installed Feedback, but getting no option to create feedback
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, the feedback activity only can be created in the same way like other modules e.g. forum, quiz and so on. If you want to use the feedback block so you have to create a feedback on the frontpage of your moodle-installation. After creation you can map some courses to that global feedback. All mapped courses now can use the feedback-block. In this block only mapped feedbacks are shown. If you don't use feedbacks on the frontpage you never need the feedback-block. You only need the feedback-activity. Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gathering information on students
ResponsesInList.Text: If you have permissions to add new modules to your Moodle then check out the questionnaire module or the feedback modules (in the downloads tab on this page>modules and plugins) They will do just what you want - in fact,we use them for similar type stuff at our place.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gathering information on students
ResponsesInList.Text: Darren, You can gather both types of information using the Feedback module. However, there is one VERY BIG caveat. If you are satisfied with viewing the information summarized within Moodle, it works great. However, if you want to export the data so that you can analyze it (e.g., in worksheet or CSV format that can be imported into a spreadsheet, data management, or statistical program), the Feedback module is not the way to go. The Feedback module does export the data, sort of, but it's from its own analysis. You can view each student's individual responses, and you can print them, but it's tedious. I'd love to have the ability to export the student data as analyzable data. I could then import it into Excel and/or Access and create easily printable forms to print each student's data on a page, but printing all pages with one command. As it is, I have to view each student's answers and print manually. That's tedious, at best, with a small class. Can't imagine doing it with a medium or large class. liz

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gathering information on students
ResponsesInList.Text: So that is a reason for using the Questionnaire module then, in preference, because you can export to Excel, etc

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help with install error
ResponsesInList.Text: Basic Unix Trudy, You are trying to run it out of you home directory. Apache wont have a bar of that. Home directory or user space has the least privileges. Apache will not allow a user to execute. Solution get a Unix Box you have root access to. Install Moodle under the webservers root /usr/local/www make sure the Moodle is owned by the web server user IE www group www same for moodledata. Ensure user and group can write and read to moodledata. Make sure you have all the extensions installed for php. John

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback - Mapping Feedback to courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, 1) I'm not sure what do you mean. If you use the feedback-block with feedbacks on the frontpage so you can map single courses to this feedback. 2) conditional access will be supported first on moodle 2. Currently you can define a grouping to limit the access to specific students. Andreas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback - Mapping Feedback to courses
ResponsesInList.Text: From what I read - there are two ways to use this feature: Globally or per course. Per course uses the mod as an activity but you can only access the reports per courses - which is time consuming for an administrator. We are using 1.8 on MySQL and the block wouldnt work, but¬†we wanted it to appear as an activity in the syllabus rather than a block within the course as the students might consider it very optional rather than part of the course. So here's the step by step of what we did: 1) Install feedback module and create an instance of the Feedback Survey on the HOME page of Moodle.¬† Create the questions and save. 2) To map the courses - type in something to filter your course selections with.¬† All our course shortcodes include the term month (_Apr).¬† This builds a list to select from. 3) Once the survey is complete and the courses have been added - you can add the survey link to the actual courses.¬†¬†¬† I used the following:¬†¬† Add resource, Add link to file or website.¬† The URL used was the¬†direct link to the survey in the HOME¬†course¬†with an added parameter of courseid = Course.id¬†¬† This ensures that the data¬†is associated with the course. Any course that has this link that is not mapped yet - should display an error.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback - Mapping Feedback to courses
ResponsesInList.Text: revised post - the block did work - I was doing things in the wrong order ... thanks Andreas!

ResponsesInList.Title: Aggregation of Feedback results across whole Moodle site
ResponsesInList.Text: I work for a FE College in the UK. Our moodle has around 700 courses on it, and depending on the students on the course, they are asked to complete one of four surveys using Feedback. The problem is that while the results of the feedback are visible within the scope of the course, the survey is a cross-college survey and as such we need the Feedback to be in the scope of the whole Moodle, if that makes sense. (Basically, we need details of every survey collated together on one page.) I have seen that a Feedback can be palced onto the front page of Moodle, but then it does not collect the course the student is taking, or the Teacher of the course, which we also need. Our current solution is to hack out some PHP which queries the feedback tables in the database directly, looking for instances of "Student Survey 1 - Feb 2009" or similar, and gathers results, producing a custom-build page of textual results. This page has no graphs and is not something which could easily be ported to other Moodles (id-specific user authentication and such), as well as repeating all the text in the questions, so if the questions change (which they inevitably will) the code neds changing too. Is there the possibility that Feedback can be extended to include surveys in the global scope? Ideally we need more information to be collected which we do not currently store in Moodle (such as which department the course is in, e.g. Hair and Beauty or Automotive) but that's for a different discuaaion thread. Regards,
